frontMatter.title: Por a Warim Hlompo Wekg (The Two Orphan Children)
frontMatter.author: Mak Kowor of Nangen village

textInfo.textTitle: Por a Warim Hlompo Wekg (The Two Orphan Children)

interlinear.free: I want to tell a story, I'm going to tell a story of before, like the ancestors would tell.
From our own land, up at Yahuwapm.
This story, it started at Yahuwapm.
At Yahuwapm then, there were two little orphans, who lived with their old grandmother.
Their mother and father had died.
So, these two children lived with their grandmother.
They lived there like that.
Now, the girl went to the garden Malhek, that her parents had made.
She took bananas, harvested pitpit, and brought it to cook and eat.
With their old grandmother they cooked food to eat.
Now the little boy went out and played ball with the other boys.
He played slide-shoot-ball for a long while, then came home, but, the grandmother had weeded the grass.
She had taken pig feces, wrapped it in leaves, and cooked it in the fire.
And she called it mushrooms.
The pig feces came from just outside the wall of the house, from a domestic pig.
Then the boy poked it with his fingernails.
And he saw the grease flow out of it.
Well, the little boy went out to play, played with the other boys a while, then came back in.
He came back inside, and then he cried.
He came inside and saw that the delicious mushrooms were gone – grandmother had taken it all, she had eaten the last one.
And so he cried.
He cried and cried and cried, and his grandmother spanked him.
That's why she hit her grandson.
I just said the reason.
She spanked him and spanked him with a limbum broom, then picked him up and carried him down to the water hole, and threw him onto a needle sago palm.
This sago palm stood at the water hole Wrep Kokg.
All this happened near Yahuwapm village.
After some time, the sister came, picked up her limbum basket and two bamboo water scoops, and carried them down to the water.
She went down and bathed, and got water to bring up to the village to cook bananas for them to eat.
However she came and searched with her eyes.
Her brother was missing, lost.
So, she went down.
She went down to the water, and heard the sound of crying up on the sago palm.
Then the sister asked, "Who is that crying?
What are you doing up there?"
"Yes, it's me!
Today grandma beat me, picked me up and threw me onto this sago branch.
So sago thorns are poking me and I'm crying.
So I was calling you, searching for you."
"Oh, I'm coming down (to you) right now."
Then she took a piece of wood which was lying on the ground, put it up against the sago branch, and walked up it and picked up her brother.
She carried him down to the ground, removed all the sago thorns, washed all his wounds, and then the two of them went up.
They went up to Yahuwapm village, they cooked bananas, put the pot on the fire, prepared greens. The girl and her little brother cooked food – the grandmother sat there.
She had beat her grandson, so she just sat there, not saying anything to them, not laughing at all, she just sat there.
After the two children finished eating, and sat for a while, then they slept.
They slept.
In the morning, the grandmother came and sat outside with the others, warming themselves in the sun. The two grandchildren prepared themselves.
After they were ready, she told her little brother, "Let's go, to search for grasshoppers for you.
Yesterday she hit you because you asked for meat.
We'll search for grasshoppers for you down at the river, and come back.
We'll dig out grasshoppers for you down at the stream.
And come back up and cook them for you to eat.
Because you cried for meat.
As for her meat, she has eaten it all."
So, the two of them went down.
They went down to the stream, they went down the Mnipwilm stream and dug for grasshoppers, until they arrived at the river.
They turned back upriver at a shallow place with stones, and saw the big stream Kemi go down.
They they saw a bandicoot stomach that was very soft.
"This bandicoot stomach, did a dog kill and eat it?
And throw it down."
The two children went up the stream. They searched for grasshoppers as they went up, on both sides of the stream. They went up, then they saw a pig's stomach.
They kept going up, searching for grasshoppers along the stream Kemi.
from side to side along the stream.
The little brother and his sister, they continued to go upstream.
They went up, and saw more and more fresh pig stomachs in the water.
Bandicoot stomachs, bird stomachs, pig stomachs, they picked them up and threw them into her limbum basket, as they went up the stream.
They went upstream, and saw more and more fresh pig stomachs.
New fresh ones, they cut them,
They cut them, washed them, wrapped them in leaves, and put them in the little limbum basket, still following the stream.
They continued up, did the same with the new pig stomachs.
They went up so far that there was no good path up the mountain. It was the waterfall where Warnu lives. The sister said,
"Wait for me, I'm cutting the new pig stomach, which was thrown out yesterday."
The little boy sat down, but no.
Warnu threw a pig stomach down.
Then water splashed toward them and they cried out.
"Whoa, the water's coming to us!"
"Huh?
Who's digging around down in my rubbish pile?"
"The two of us are cutting pig stomachs, to cook and eat them."
"My dears, why don't you come up here!"
Quickly he removed a bamboo pole, brought it and slid it down.
He slid it down the waterfall, placed it, and the sister said,
"You sit here for now, I'll go by myself first.
What if he is the type of man who would kill us and eat us?
He would kill me and eat me."
But, the brother said, "I want to go up with you."
She said, "Nope, stay here.
I'll go up and see first, then I'll come back down for you and we'll go up."
She went up the bamboo, until she arrived. He picked up the bamboo, put it aside, and called to her, "Come here!"
The two of them went to the house, and saw the pig meat lying all over the house.
Fresh meat, still red with blood.
Then Warnu said to her,
"Here is meat, feel free to cook it in the fire, and eat some."
She cooked pig meat in the fire, and ate it. Then she went to the side of the mountain and looked down with her hand covering her eyes.
She looked down the mountain.
The old man saw her and asked her,
"What are you searching for?"
"I'm looking at my little brother, he's down there at the base of the waterfall."
"That's great – I'll put the bamboo pole down again.
For him to come up here.
He can come up and we'll live together.
There's room for plenty of people, because I live by myself."
Yeah right!
He deceived them with these words, in order to eat them.
The boy came up the bamboo pole, and the two of them stayed there.
Then the brother and sister said,
"We have no dry coconuts with which to cook these grasshoppers."
"No," (he said).
(He said,) "There's coconuts, right up there."
Taking the rope out (of his house) and giving it to the boy, he said, "You go up and get some coconuts, go up and shake the ripe ones down."
The boy went up the coconut palm and shook the dry ones down. The coconuts dropped down to the house of the old woman Hkarik.
The woman Hkarik came out and picked up the coconuts and put them inside her house.
He finished removing the coconuts and came down, he jumped down to the ground. And the sister said, "I'm going to go down and find the coconuts.
You stay here at the coconut palm and keep your eyes on me."
She went down to search for the coconuts, she went down and met the old woman Hkarik.
And Hkarik said,
"What are you two doing today, that you came to see Warnu?
The old man Warnu is bad – he eats people!
He'll eat anything (with hair on it).
People too.
He'll eat people too."
After she finished explaining to her, she said, "Go on up and cook your grasshoppers, and make a plate of it for me too.
Put food for me in a big shell plate. When I go up, I will eat it.
Be sure not to enter the house before him.
The house is bad.
If you go inside, you will go up the anus of the old man Warnu.
He eats children, men, women, everyone. They all go up his anus."
That night, they were sitting with Warnu, and then he asked them,
"Shall we go to sleep?"
But the two of them said, "We're hot, we'll sit out here yet."

He went inside as if to prepare beds for them but no, after he 'prepared' 'kringkrung kringkrung,' he came and put one foot on one side of the doorway, and the other food on the other doorpost. Inside (of his body), a fire crackled.
The children thought he was lighting a lamp for them.
Yeah right!
It was his heart giving light like a fire.
Then the grandmother Hkarik came up, and told them,
"You two follow me, I'll show you what to do."
The two children stood back for her to act first.
She stood back and pushed a burning log up into the anus of Warnu.
One went up then another went up.
After that, he closed his anus.
And went up into his house to sleep.
They gathered the plates of cooked grasshoppers, and disappeared!
Hkarik took the children and they went down.
Down to the house of the old woman Hkarik.
After Warnu thought he ate the children, he felt hot and went to find water to drink. He drank and drank, but still felt very hot. So he went up.
He went up to the lake.
At the lake, he drank water and bathed in the water and stayed there.
He drank all the water in the lake, and he went up.
He went up to another lake (a bigger one).
After a while, he died up in the second lake. His bones and flesh rotted, then two dogs came and took his two testicles and left them at the lakeshore.
The owners of these two dogs saw this, and took the two testicles home and used them to make magic potions.
All the people saw this, and took Warnu's bones and stuff home for making magic potions.
The people of Nangen, the people of Suau, the people of Womerau, the people of Womgrer, we got this for making the magic potions.
That's all.
The story finishes here.
